questions.text: Given y=f(u)y = f(u)y=f(u) and u=g(x)u = g(x)u=g(x), what is the general formula for dydx\frac{dy}{dx}dxdy​ according to the Chain Rule?

options.text: dydx=f′(u)⋅g′(x)\frac{dy}{dx} = f'(u) \cdot g'(x)dxdy​=f′(u)⋅g′(x)
dydx=f′(x)⋅g′(u)\frac{dy}{dx} = f'(x) \cdot g'(u)dxdy​=f′(x)⋅g′(u)
dydx=f′(u)+g′(x)\frac{dy}{dx} = f'(u) + g'(x)dxdy​=f′(u)+g′(x)
dydx=f′(g(x))\frac{dy}{dx} = f'(g(x))dxdy​=f′(g(x))

questions.explanation: The Chain Rule states that the derivative of a composite function is the derivative of the outer function evaluated at the inner function, multiplied by the derivative of the inner function.

questions.text: Calculate the derivative of h(x)=(3x+1)2h(x) = (3x + 1)^2h(x)=(3x+1)2.

options.text: 6(3x+1)6(3x + 1)6(3x+1)
2(3x+1)2(3x + 1)2(3x+1)
6x+16x + 16x+1
9x2+19x^2 + 19x2+1

questions.explanation: Let u=3x+1u = 3x+1u=3x+1, so h=u2h = u^2h=u2. dhdu=2u\frac{dh}{du} = 2ududh​=2u and dudx=3\frac{du}{dx} = 3dxdu​=3. dhdx=2(3x+1)⋅3=6(3x+1)\frac{dh}{dx} = 2(3x+1) \cdot 3 = 6(3x+1)dxdh​=2(3x+1)⋅3=6(3x+1).

questions.text: If y=sin⁡(x2)y = \sin(x^2)y=sin(x2), what is dydx\frac{dy}{dx}dxdy​?

options.text: 2xcos⁡(x2)2x \cos(x^2)2xcos(x2)
cos⁡(x2)\cos(x^2)cos(x2)
2xsin⁡(x2)2x \sin(x^2)2xsin(x2)
cos⁡(2x)\cos(2x)cos(2x)

questions.explanation: The outer function is sin⁡(⋅)\sin(\cdot)sin(⋅) and the inner function is x2x^2x2. Derivative of sin⁡(u)\sin(u)sin(u) is cos⁡(u)\cos(u)cos(u). Derivative of x2x^2x2 is 2x2x2x. Result: cos⁡(x2)⋅2x\cos(x^2) \cdot 2xcos(x2)⋅2x.

questions.text: Find the derivative of f(x)=e5xf(x) = e^{5x}f(x)=e5x.

options.text: 5e5x5e^{5x}5e5x
e5xe^{5x}e5x
5xe5x−15xe^{5x-1}5xe5x−1
15e5x\frac{1}{5}e^{5x}51​e5x

questions.explanation: The derivative of eue^ueu is eu⋅u′e^u \cdot u'eu⋅u′. Here u=5xu=5xu=5x, so u′=5u'=5u′=5.

questions.text: Differentiate y=ln⁡(cos⁡x)y = \ln(\cos x)y=ln(cosx).

options.text: −tan⁡x-\tan x−tanx
1cos⁡x\frac{1}{\cos x}cosx1​
−sin⁡x-\sin x−sinx
1sin⁡x\frac{1}{\sin x}sinx1​

questions.explanation: dydx=1cos⁡x⋅ddx(cos⁡x)=1cos⁡x⋅(−sin⁡x)=−tan⁡x\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{1}{\cos x} \cdot \frac{d}{dx}(\cos x) = \frac{1}{\cos x} \cdot (-\sin x) = -\tan xdxdy​=cosx1​⋅dxd​(cosx)=cosx1​⋅(−sinx)=−tanx.

questions.text: If f(x)=1+x2f(x) = \sqrt{1 + x^2}f(x)=1+x2​, what is f′(x)f'(x)f′(x)?

options.text: x1+x2\frac{x}{\sqrt{1 + x^2}}1+x2​x​
121+x2\frac{1}{2\sqrt{1 + x^2}}21+x2​1​
2x1+x2\frac{2x}{\sqrt{1 + x^2}}1+x2​2x​
x1+x2x\sqrt{1+x^2}x1+x2​

questions.explanation: Rewrite as (1+x2)1/2(1+x^2)^{1/2}(1+x2)1/2. Power rule: 12(1+x2)−1/2\frac{1}{2}(1+x^2)^{-1/2}21​(1+x2)−1/2. Chain: Multiply by 2x2x2x. 12(1+x2)−1/2⋅2x=x1+x2\frac{1}{2}(1+x^2)^{-1/2} \cdot 2x = \frac{x}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}21​(1+x2)−1/2⋅2x=1+x2​x​.

questions.text: In the function h(x)=sin⁡(cos⁡(x))h(x) = \sin(\cos(x))h(x)=sin(cos(x)), which is the "inner" function?

options.text: cos⁡(x)\cos(x)cos(x)
sin⁡(x)\sin(x)sin(x)
xxx

questions.explanation: The function applied first to xxx is the inner function. Here, you calculate cos⁡(x)\cos(x)cos(x) before taking the sine of the result.

questions.text: If matrix AAA has dimensions 3×23 \times 23×2 and matrix BBB has dimensions 2×42 \times 42×4, what are the dimensions of the product ABABAB?

options.text: 3×43 \times 43×4
2×22 \times 22×2
4×34 \times 34×3
Multiplication is not possible.

questions.explanation: The inner dimensions must match (222 and 222). The resulting matrix takes the outer dimensions (333 and 444).

questions.text:
Calculate the product:

[12]×[34]\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \times \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}[1​2​]×[34​]

options.text: [11][11][11]
[38]\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 8 \end{bmatrix}[3​8​]
[38]\begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 8 \end{bmatrix}[38​]
[7][7][7]

questions.explanation: This is a dot product of a row and a column. (1×3)+(2×4)=3+8=11(1 \times 3) + (2 \times 4) = 3 + 8 = 11(1×3)+(2×4)=3+8=11.

questions.text: Which of the following is generally true regarding matrix multiplication?

options.text: It is associative: (AB)C=A(BC)(AB)C = A(BC)(AB)C=A(BC).
It is commutative: AB=BAAB = BAAB=BA.
It works for any two matrices regardless of size.
options.rawText: It works for any two matrices regardless of size.

questions.explanation: Matrix multiplication is associative but generally not commutative (AB≠BAAB \neq BAAB=BA usually).

questions.text: Multiply the Identity matrix III by any compatible matrix AAA. What is the result?

options.text: AAA
III
000
A2A^2A2

questions.explanation: The identity matrix acts like the number 1 in scalar multiplication. AI=AAI = AAI=A and IA=AIA = AIA=A.

questions.text:
Given:

A=[0110],B=[2345]A = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}, B = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 \end{bmatrix}A=[01​10​],B=[24​35​]

Calculate ABABAB.

options.text: [4523]\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 5 \\ 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix}[42​53​]
[0340]\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ 4 & 0 \end{bmatrix}[04​30​]
[2345]\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 \end{bmatrix}[24​35​]

questions.explanation: Matrix A is a permutation matrix; it swaps the rows of B. Row 1 of result: 0(2)+1(4)=40(2)+1(4)=40(2)+1(4)=4, 0(3)+1(5)=50(3)+1(5)=50(3)+1(5)=5. Row 2 of result: 1(2)+0(4)=21(2)+0(4)=21(2)+0(4)=2, 1(3)+0(5)=31(3)+0(5)=31(3)+0(5)=3.

questions.text: For matrix multiplication ABABAB to be valid, the number of _____ in A must equal the number of _____ in B.

options.text: columns; rows
rows; columns
rows; rows
columns; columns

questions.explanation: This is the dimension compatibility rule: (m×n)×(n×p)(m \times n) \times (n \times p)(m×n)×(n×p).

questions.text:
What is the element at row 1, column 1 of the product of these matrices?

[abcd][efgh]\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} e & f \\ g & h \end{bmatrix}[ac​bd​][eg​fh​]

options.text: ae+bgae + bgae+bg
ae+bfae + bfae+bf
af+bhaf + bhaf+bh
ce+dgce + dgce+dg

questions.explanation: Take Row 1 of the first matrix [a,b][a, b][a,b] and dot it with Column 1 of the second matrix [e,g]T[e, g]^T[e,g]T. Result: ae+bgae + bgae+bg.

questions.text: What is the transpose of the row vector v=[123]v = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix}v=[1​2​3​]?

options.text: [123]\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}​123​​
[321]\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}[3​2​1​]
[−1−2−3]\begin{bmatrix} -1 & -2 & -3 \end{bmatrix}[−1​−2​−3​]

questions.explanation: Transposing switches rows and columns. A 1×31 \times 31×3 row vector becomes a 3×13 \times 13×1 column vector.

AijA_{ij}Aij​

options.text: BTATB^T A^TBTAT
ATBTA^T B^TATBT
ATBA^T BATB
ABTAB^TABT

questions.text: If a matrix AAA is equal to its transpose (A=ATA = A^TA=AT), the matrix is called:

options.text: Symmetric
Skew-symmetric
Identity
Inverse

questions.explanation: A symmetric matrix is mirror-imaged across its main diagonal.

A−1A^{-1}A−1

options.text: [2002]\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}[20​02​]
[1234]\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}[13​24​]

questions.explanation:
The Identity matrix and any diagonal matrix are symmetric.
Option 1: Row 1 is [2 0], Col 1 is [2 0]. Row 2 is [0 2], Col 2 is [0 2]. They match.

questions.text: In Supervised Learning, the dataset consists of:

options.text: Input features and corresponding output labels
options.rawText: Input features and corresponding output labels

options.text: Only input features
Only output labels
Unstructured data with no goals

questions.explanation: Supervised learning requires "ground truth" labels (targets) to train the model to map inputs to outputs.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Classification problem?

options.text: Predicting if an email is "Spam" or "Not Spam"
options.rawText: Predicting if an email is "Spam" or "Not Spam"

options.text: Predicting the price of a house
options.rawText: Predicting the price of a house

options.text: Predicting the temperature for tomorrow
Grouping customers by purchasing habits (without predefined groups)
options.rawText: Grouping customers by purchasing habits (without predefined groups)

questions.explanation: Classification predicts discrete categories/classes. The others are Regression (price, temp) or Clustering (grouping).

questions.text: What phenomenon occurs when a model learns the training data too well, including the noise, and performs poorly on new data?

options.text: Overfitting
Underfitting
Regularization
Bias

questions.explanation: Overfitting is like memorizing the answers to a practice test but failing the real exam because you didn't learn the concepts.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a "Test Set"?

options.text: To evaluate the final performance of the model on unseen data
options.rawText: To evaluate the final performance of the model on unseen data

options.text: To train the model parameters
To tune hyperparameters
To increase the size of the training data
options.rawText: To increase the size of the training data

questions.explanation: The test set acts as a proxy for real-world data to ensure the model generalizes well. It is never used for training.

questions.text: In the context of neural networks, what is a "Loss Function"?

options.text: A mathematical way to measure how far the model's predictions are from the actual targets
options.rawText: A mathematical way to measure how far the model's predictions are from the actual targets

options.text: A function that deletes data
The accuracy of the model expressed as a percentage
options.rawText: The accuracy of the model expressed as a percentage

options.text: An algorithm for sorting data

questions.explanation: The loss function (or cost function) quantifies the error. The goal of training is to minimize this value.

questions.text: Which of these is a Hyperparameter?

options.text: The Learning Rate
The weights inside the neuron
The bias term inside the neuron
options.rawText: The bias term inside the neuron

options.text: The predicted output value

questions.explanation: Hyperparameters are settings chosen before training begins (like learning rate, number of layers). Weights and biases are parameters learned during training.

questions.text: What is Gradient Descent?

options.text: An optimization algorithm used to minimize the loss function
options.rawText: An optimization algorithm used to minimize the loss function

options.text: A method for visualizing data
A type of neural network layer
options.rawText: A type of neural network layer

options.text: A technique for data cleaning

questions.explanation: Gradient Descent iteratively adjusts parameters by moving in the opposite direction of the gradient (the slope) to find the minimum error.

dfdx\frac{df}{dx}dxdf​
f⋅xf \cdot xf⋅x
Δfx\Delta f_xΔfx​

questions.explanation: We use the stylized "curly d" (∂\partial∂) to denote partial derivatives, distinguishing them from ordinary derivatives (ddd).

questions.text: Given f(x,y)=3x2y+5y3f(x, y) = 3x^2y + 5y^3f(x,y)=3x2y+5y3, find ∂f∂x\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}∂x∂f​.

6xy+5y36xy + 5y^36xy+5y3
6x6x6x

xeyx e^yxey

questions.text: The vector composed of all first-order partial derivatives of a scalar function is called the:

options.text: Gradient
Jacobian
Hessian
Determinant

questions.explanation: The gradient, denoted ∇f\nabla f∇f, is the vector [∂f∂x,∂f∂y,… ][\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}, \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}, \dots][∂x∂f​,∂y∂f​,…].

options.text: The volume under the surface.
The curvature of the surface.

questions.explanation: It represents the rate of change of the function value as you move purely along the x-axis, holding y constant.

questions.text: The probability of an event P(A)P(A)P(A) must always satisfy:

options.text: 0≤P(A)≤10 \leq P(A) \leq 10≤P(A)≤1
0<P(A)<10 < P(A) < 10<P(A)<1
−1≤P(A)≤1-1 \leq P(A) \leq 1−1≤P(A)≤1
P(A)≥1P(A) \geq 1P(A)≥1

questions.explanation: Probabilities are defined as values between 0 (impossible) and 1 (certain).

questions.text: If events AAA and BBB are independent, what is P(A and B)P(A \text{ and } B)P(A and B)?

options.text: P(A)×P(B)P(A) \times P(B)P(A)×P(B)
P(A)+P(B)P(A) + P(B)P(A)+P(B)
P(A)/P(B)P(A) / P(B)P(A)/P(B)
000

questions.explanation: Independence implies that the occurrence of A has no effect on B. The joint probability is the product of the marginal probabilities.

questions.text: You roll a standard 6-sided die. What is the probability of rolling a number greater than 4?

options.text: 1/31/31/3
1/61/61/6
1/21/21/2
2/32/32/3

questions.explanation: The numbers greater than 4 are 5 and 6. That is 2 outcomes. Total outcomes = 6. Probability = 2/6=1/32/6 = 1/32/6=1/3.

questions.text: If the probability of it raining tomorrow is 0.30.30.3, what is the probability that it does not rain?

options.text: 0.70.70.7
0.30.30.3
−0.3-0.3−0.3
0.00.00.0

questions.explanation: The sum of probabilities for an event and its complement must equal 1. 1−0.3=0.71 - 0.3 = 0.71−0.3=0.7.

questions.text: Which term describes two events that cannot happen at the same time?

options.text: Mutually Exclusive
Independent
Conditional
Correlated

questions.explanation: If AAA happens, BBB cannot. P(A∩B)=0P(A \cap B) = 0P(A∩B)=0.

questions.text: What is the formula for Conditional Probability P(A∣B)P(A|B)P(A∣B)?

options.text: P(A∩B)P(B)\frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}P(B)P(A∩B)​
P(A)P(B)\frac{P(A)}{P(B)}P(B)P(A)​
P(A)×P(B)P(A) \times P(B)P(A)×P(B)
P(A)−P(B)P(A) - P(B)P(A)−P(B)

questions.explanation: P(A∣B)P(A|B)P(A∣B) is the probability of A given B has occurred. It restricts the sample space to B.

questions.text: A bag contains 3 Red balls and 2 Blue balls. You pick one, keep it, and pick another. Are these events independent?

options.text: No
Yes

questions.explanation: This is sampling "without replacement." Removing the first ball changes the total number of balls and the ratio of colors for the second draw, so the probabilities change.
